Award.AwardTitle: CRIF:MU - Acquisition of a Q-TOF Mass Spectrometer for Departmental Research and Education in Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities: Multi-user (CRIF:MU) program, Professor Richard Jordan and colleagues Chuan He, Gregory Hillhouse, Rustem Ismagilov and Hisashi Yamamoto from the University of Chicago will acquire a quadrupole-time-of-flight (Q-TOF) mass spectrometer coupled to a liquid chromatograph. The proposal will enhance research training and education at all levels, especially in areas of study such as (a) synthesis, reactivity and mechanisms of Group 4 metallocene catalysts, (b) group transfer reactions of low-coordinate nickel, (c) metal aryl oxides for catalytic organic transformations, (d) transition metal mediated carbon-carbon bond and C-heteroatom bond formation via C-H activation in organic synthesis, (e) chemical approaches to glial-neuronal networks, and (f) modular assemblies for controlling the cell-material interfaces.

This mass spectrometer (Q-TOF) will be coupled to a high-resolution liquid chromatography system. This combines the physical separation capability of liquid chromatography with the mass analysis ability of mass spectrometry. The liquid chromatograph separates a mixture into its molecular components. These components flow into a mass spectrometer where their masses, and those of their fragments, are measured. A Q-TOF mass spectrometer is a special design that provides high mass accuracy, sensitivity and resolution that allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. The instrumentation will be used not only for research but also in laboratory courses to train significant numbers of students in the use of this important analytical technique and for outreach activities with Chicago public high schools and nearby universities such as Chicago State University, Governors State University, Northeastern Illinois University and Roosevelt University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. The goal of this project was to acquire a liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) instrument to enhance research and education within the molecular sciences at the University of Chicago. The LC-MS experiment involves separation of the molecular components of a sample by flowing a solution of the sample through a column that differentially absorbs the components (LC), and subsequent in-line characterization of the molecular components by ionization and measurement of their mass/charge ratios and fragmentation patterns (MS). This technique provides a powerful means of characterizing of diverse molecular and biomolecular samples. An Agilent 6540 quadrupole time-of-flight (Q-Tof) spectrometer coupled with a 1200 liquid chromatograph (LC) was purchased and installed in the Department of Chemistry Mass Spectrometry Center. Users from many departments, including the Department of Chemistry, Institute for Biophysical Dynamics, James Franck Institute, Department of Ecology & Evolution, Ben May Department for Cancer Research, Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Department of Surgery and Institute for Molecular Engineering, have utilized the instrument. The instrument has enabled studies of synthetic and catalytic transformations, the characterization of intermediates in organic and inorganic reactions, and accurate mass determination of organic, organometallic, inorganic and biological samples. New low-coordinate Ni carbene complexes that are of interest for catalytic olefin cyclopropanation have been prepared and their oxidation chemistry explored. New organometallic complexes that are of interest for the copolymerization of olefins with polar vinyl monomers and the activation of carbon dioxide have been prepared and their dynamics and, reactivity explored. Artificial metalloenzymes that incorporate a manganese terpyridine reaction center within protein scaffolds have been prepared and shown to be active for C-H bond functionalization processes, opening the door to optimization of performance and selectivity through directed protein evolution. New enantioselective catalytic processes that are useful for the synthesis of complex organic molecules have been developed. Synthetic models for light-harvesting systems have been prepared and provided insights to the factors that control long-lived electronic coherences in photo-generated excited states. New modifications of mammalian messenger RNA have been discovered and shown to be important in the regulation of gene expression and mRNA degradation. A high through-put system for screening large numbers of potential chemical reactions in order to discover previously unknown catalytic transformations has been developed and used to develop new benzannulation reactions. The LC-MS characterization of small molecules, organometallics, metal complexes and biomolecules has been critical for all these advances. The fundamental research that has been enabled by this project will provide the basis for future applications in the chemical, pharmaceutical and polymer industries as well as the development of artificial photosynthetic systems for solar energy conversion and new medical diagnostics and therapeutics.

Broader Impact. This project has contributed to the development of human resources in science through the education of postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, undergraduates and high school students. Additionally, students in the undergraduate organic chemistry laboratory have had samples analyzed by this instrument, which has contributed to their training.
